title: Ticket #227: Benchmark new classads vs. old
description:
Benchmark New ClassAds against old ClassAds

Summary

Before switching to new classads, we should do a quick benchmarking of the code against old classads, just to make sure that there are no big surprises. We need to measure both CPU and memory usage of common operations: insert, lookup, parsing, and matching.

Benchmarks to perform

  1. A benchmark that instantiates N classads, adds A attributes into it, and then deletes them. Compare execution time and size b/w new and old classads. Nick DONE

  2. A benchmark that instantiates N classads, then does a constraint evaluation on all of them. Compare execution time and size b/w new and old classads. Nick DONE

  3. Grab the output of condor_status -l off one of the collectors (?) on a pool to get all the machine classads in the pool into a text file. Suck this up into a program which instantiates a classad for each of these machines. (Maybe make 10 instances of classads for each machine to magnify results). Check memory footprint; compare b/w new and old classads. Nick Done

  4. Similarly with a job queue, grab the job classads, and suck them into a program which instantiates classads for each job in the text file. (Magnify as needed). Check memory footprint; compare b/w new and old classads. Nick Done

One of the concerns is that old classads do a reference counting of strings, whereas new classads use C++ strings. Check how much of an impact this would be especially when:

  1. job ads contain entire environment.
  2. repetitious strings like condor version string are repeated across multiple machine ads across the pool.

Summary of results

  1. Instantiate, fill, delete N classads
    • New ClassAds seem to consistently run this benchmark faster, up to 2x, depending on the mix of the "input" data, the frequency of duplicate strings, etc.
    • New ClassAds seem to consistently use less memory, as well, about 2/3 that of old ClassAds, again depending on the mix.

  2. Matching
    • Memory use between the two is very close, with new ClassAds consistently using about 96% of the RAM compared to old ClassAds.
    • Old ClassAds performed 4.7x faster than new ClassAds.

  3. Instantiate "real" machine ads
    • New ClassAds used a very similar amount of memory (very slightly less) that old ClassAds in these tests
    • New ClassAds performed at approximately 56% (instantiations / second) compared to old ClassAds.

  4. Instantiate "real" job ads
    • In this benchmark, old ClassAds were both faster and consumed less memory than new classads.
    • Old ClassAds performed 2.3x faster than new ClassAds
    • New ClassAds used 1.4x the amount of RAM compared to old ClassAds

Running the bencharks

  1. Instantiate, fill, delete N classads
    • New: ./cabench_inst-new 5 inst.attrs 10000 1000
    • Old: ./cabench_inst-old 5 inst.attrs 10000 1000

  2. Matching
    • New: ./cabench_query-newlist --enable-2way 3 collector.ads-new 10000 '[Requirements = (other.Arch == "X86_64"); JobUniverse = 5; ]'
    • Old:

  3. Instantiate "real" machine ads
    • New: ./cabench_query-newlist 0 collector.ads-new '*10' - --filter '[Requirements = (other.MyType == "Machine") ]'
    • Old:

  4. Instantiate "real" job ads
    • New: ./cabench_query-newlist 3 jobs-newbio.ads-new '*10' -
    • Old: ./cabench_query-oldlist 3 jobs-newbio.ads-old '*10' -
remarks:
2009-Mar-30 14:33:15 by nleroy:

Benchmark 2:

 

./classad_benchmark_constraint-new --view 'other.MyType == "Machine"' --enable-2way all.newad 10000 10 '[Requirements = (other.Arch == "X86_64"); JobUniverse = 5; ]'
searches                    10 in  4.15679s => 0.4156794sp       2.41/s
Total Ads               100000 in  4.15679s => 0.0000416sp   24057.00/s
Total View Members       53930 in  4.15679s => 0.0000771sp   12973.94/s
Total Query matches      10380 in  4.15679s => 0.0004005sp    2497.12/s

./classad_benchmark_constraint-new --disable-view --enable-2way all.newad 10000 10 '[Requirements = (other.Arch == "X86_64" && other.MyType == "Machine"); JobUniverse = 5; ]'
searches                     10 in  6.07513s => 0.6075133sp       1.65/s
Total Ads                100000 in  6.07513s => 0.0000608sp   16460.54/s
Total View Members       100000 in  6.07513s => 0.0000608sp   16460.54/s
Total Query matches       10200 in  6.07513s => 0.0005956sp    1678.98/s

./classad_benchmark_constraint-old --disable-view --enable-2way all.oldad 10000 10 '[Requirements = (Arch == "X86_64"); JobUniverse = 5; MyType="Job"; TargetType="Machine" ]'
searches                     10 in  1.59872s => 0.1598716sp       6.26/s
Total Ads                100000 in  1.59872s => 0.0000160sp   62550.20/s
Total View Members       100000 in  1.59872s => 0.0000160sp   62550.20/s
Total Query matches        9790 in  1.59872s => 0.0001633sp    6123.66/s

2009-Apr-01 12:40:20 by tannenba:
The above looks good for new ClasAds. I am wondering, however, why the number of ads that match the constraint varies across the three tests. Is the input data not controlled?

2009-Apr-01 12:55:04 by matt:
Can you give numbers when running the same constraint on both new and old classads?

They are running with the same constraints. The differences that you see are due to the fact that old ClassAds automagically compare MyType and TargetType of the ads, and new ClassAds doesn't have such a concept, so I had to build that into my query.

Can you explain what the numbers mean? It looks like new classads are 3-4 times slower when matching and 4-5 times slower for whatever ads and view members is?

2009-Apr-01 14:41 by nleroy:

To Todd:

For better or for worse, the current benchmark is told to generate n (in the above case 10000) ads based on a 'snapshot' of condor_status -any -l. As it goes through and adds more ads, there is a degree of randomness as to which of the original ads (from the snapshot) it bases the next ad to add to the collection from. So, in one run there might be more schedd ads, then next more X86_64 ads, etc.

To Matt:

Old classads doesn't have a view concept. Or, rather it may have at some point (it referended in some header files), but has since been disabled. New classads collections allows the application to create a distinct 'view' of the collection that matches a given constraint. In the above, I used 'other.MyType == "Machine" to specify the view, so the view view that I then queried is a sub-set of the entire ClassAd collection.

Yes, you're right, the new ClassAd collection code does appear to be slower to query than that of old ClassAds. That being said, old ClassAds doesn't even have a real query -- it allows you to iterate through the collection and pick out ads that match, which is what the current collector does. I haven't looked at all into any possible optimizations that could be done to new ClassAds collection queries.

2009-Apr-01 15:35:54 by matt:
Nick, it is impossible to follow the comments if you edit them instead of appending.

2009-Apr-29 14:58:00 by nleroy:
OK, I have benchmarks based on walking through an STL list of ads, matching one at a time. I've run these tests with list<>s of 10,000 up to 50,000 ads. At 100,000 the image size of the process grew large enough that I eventually gave up and killed the process.

The timings seem pretty consistent.. Old ClassAds do match-making about 5x to 6x faster than new ClassAds. This is consistent through a wide range of list sizes.

Memory use between the two is very close, with new ClassAds consistently using about 96% of the RAM compared to old ClassAds.

All of these measurements seem to remain constant with scaling from 10,000 up to 50,000 ads. At 50,000 ads, new ClassAds contributed 826,428M to the test program's image size, while old ClassAds used 855,816M. Again, the ratio between the two is very consistent.

2009-Apr-30 15:18:40 by nleroy:
I just completed an update that allows the test to "pre-filter" ads such that it'll run the query against a subset of ads -- in this case jobs with MyType == "Machine". This had little affect on the performance of old ClassAds (not surprizing), and sped up new ClassAds somewhat. This was an attempt to better emulate the behavior of the negotiator.

Under these conditions, old ClassAds performed 4.7x faster than new ClassAds.

Memory usage patters, not surprisingly, were not affected by this.

2009-Apr-30 15:21:18 by nleroy:
This benchmarking work is being done on it's own branch: V7_3-new_classads_benchmarks-branch

There's also the V7_3-new_classads-branch branch which is intended to be updates and additions to new ClassAds without the benchmarks. The benchmarks branch is based off the this branch.

2009-May-14 15:38:15 by nleroy:

Benchmark 3 (instantiate ads from 'condor_status -l' results)

summary

New ClassAds used a very similar amount of memory (very slightly less) that old ClassAds in these tests, but performed at approximately 56% (instantiations / second) compared to old ClassAds.

Old ClassAds

On tonic, old ClassAds consistently instantiates about 1100 ads / second (as read from a file), using 341188k to instantiate 13150 machine ads (10x) (about 26.0k per ad). 
Target: 13150 ads
setup @ 1242332853.07s: 7532k 2640k
  done            13150 in 11.95430s => 0.0009091sp    1100.02/s
  done                 @  11.95430s   341180k   341188k [diff]

New ClassAds

On tonic, new ClassAds consistently instantiates about 620 ads / second (as read from a file), using 337196k to instantiate 13150 machine ads (10x) (about 25.6k per ad). 
Target: 13150 ads
setup @ 1242332832.55s: 7548k 2648k
  done            13150 in 21.17745s => 0.0016105sp     620.94/s
  done                 @  21.17745s   337124k   337196k [diff]

2009-May-14 18:35:38 by nleroy:

Results for benchmark 4 (instantiation of job ads)

 The job ads for this test were pulled from the schedd on 'newbio'; I have no idea how representative they are of other workloads.

Summary

In this benchmark, old classads were both faster and consumed less memory than new classads. Old classads performed 2.3x faster than new classads, while new classads used 1.4x the amount of RAM.

Old ClassAds

The old classad code instantiated 35720 ads at a rate of about 1400 ads / second, using a total of 514672k of RAM (14.4k / ad). 

Target: 35720 ads
setup @ 1242343502.23s: 7688k 2908k
  done            35720 in 25.55164s => 0.0007153sp    1397.95/s
  done                 @  25.55164s   514704k   514672k [diff]

New ClassAds

The new classad code instantiated 35720 ads at a rate of about 600 ads / second, consuming 713252k of RAM (20.0k / ad). 

Target: 35720 ads
setup @ 1242343574.07s: 7760k 2952k
  done            35720 in 59.22017s => 0.0016579sp     603.17/s
  done                 @  59.22017s   713308k   713252k [diff]

2009-May-18 15:47:34 by nleroy:

Benchmark #1 results

summary

This one is a bit more difficult to interpret.

New ClassAds seem to consistently run this benchmark faster, up to 2x, depending on the mix of the "input" data, the frequency of duplicate strings, etc.

New ClassAds seem to consistently use less memory, as well, about 2/3 that of old ClassAds, again depending on the mix.

benchmark apparatus

I created a separate Python script to generate attribute / value pairs, along with "duplicate" numbers for each. All of the attribute / value pairs are randomly generated strings (and integers and booleans). Strings, however, can have a non-zero random duplicate number that the benchmark itself uses to instantiate the same a/v pair duplicates into the number of ads. Several "classes" of strings were used, each with a different length range and duplicate probability; however the benchmark itself only "sees" a string with a duplication number. This number is actually the percentage of ads for which this a/v should be duplicated -- thus, the same data file can be used for tests with 10 ads as well as 1,000 ads.

For the benchmarks below, ran 5 loops; in each loop, 10,000 ads were created and then populated, each with 1,000 attributes. Duplicate strings were used as specified in the input data file (see above paragraph).

At the bottom of each loop, all ads were delete()ed from memory.

old ClassAd details

Under the above benchmark, old ClassAds used approximately 35716k (3.57k/ad) (each loop) to fill the ads, requiring about 41 seconds. Generating the "empty" ads used 1524k (0.15k/ad), and required about 0.003 seconds. Deletion freed 5128k (0.51k/ad) and required about 0.32 seconds. 

** loop 1 **
  init complete   10000 in  0.01580s => 0.0000016sp  632873.22/s
  init complete        @   0.01580s img:1524k (0.15k/s)      rss:1540k (0.15k/s)      [diff]
  fill complete   10000 in 41.87912s => 0.0041879sp     238.78/s
  fill complete        @  41.87912s img:35716k (3.57k/s)     rss:35760k (3.58k/s)     [diff]
  delete complete 10000 in  0.31660s => 0.0000317sp   31585.90/s
  delete complete      @   0.31660s img:-5128k (-0.51k/s)    rss:-5120k (-0.51k/s)    [diff]

** loop 2 **
  init complete   10000 in  0.00410s => 0.0000004sp 2437840.16/s
  init complete        @   0.00410s img:0k (0.00k/s)         rss:0k (0.00k/s)         [diff]
  fill complete   10000 in 42.03365s => 0.0042034sp     237.90/s
  fill complete        @  42.03365s img:35616k (3.56k/s)     rss:35564k (3.56k/s)     [diff]
  delete complete 10000 in  0.32466s => 0.0000325sp   30801.18/s
  delete complete      @   0.32466s img:-5128k (-0.51k/s)    rss:-5128k (-0.51k/s)    [diff]

new ClassAd details

New ClassAds used approximately 27204k (2.72k/ad) (each loop) to fill the ads, requiring about 21 seconds. Generating the "empty" ads used 812k (0.08k/ad) and required about 0.006 seconds. Deletion freed 0k (0.0k/ad) and required about 0.16 seconds. 

** loop 1 **
  init complete   10000 in  0.00351s => 0.0000004sp 2846683.86/s
  init complete        @   0.00351s img:812k (0.08k/s)       rss:764k (0.08k/s)       [diff]
  fill complete   10000 in 21.48621s => 0.0021486sp     465.41/s
  fill complete        @  21.48621s img:27204k (2.72k/s)     rss:27240k (2.72k/s)     [diff]
  delete complete 10000 in  0.15971s => 0.0000160sp   62613.51/s
  delete complete      @   0.15971s img:0k (0.00k/s)         rss:0k (0.00k/s)         [diff]

** loop 2 **
  init complete   10000 in  0.00268s => 0.0000003sp 3735575.35/s
  init complete        @   0.00268s img:0k (0.00k/s)         rss:0k (0.00k/s)         [diff]
  fill complete   10000 in 21.60156s => 0.0021602sp     462.93/s
  fill complete        @  21.60156s img:27196k (2.72k/s)     rss:27176k (2.72k/s)     [diff]
  delete complete 10000 in  0.18101s => 0.0000181sp   55244.69/s
  delete complete      @   0.18101s img:0k (0.00k/s)         rss:0k (0.00k/s)         [diff]

Image size strangeness

New ClassAd benchmark memory usage measurements are returning results that are confusing to me. After deleting the ads, the image size and RSS of the old ClassAds benchmark drops as expected. With new ClassAds, however, that doesn't appear to be the case. I've done some reworks on the benchmark apparatus (in case it was the apparatus I was measuring, not the ClassAd code itself), but that had no affect. At the top of the next loop, both new and old have reduced isize and RSS -- this seems normal. After the start of the second and each loop after, both had a constant isize and RSS.

For new ClassAds, this number was 752k (compared to that before the start of the first loop. For old ClassAds, this number was 1632k.

2009-Dec-01 14:37:56 by nleroy:
The files that are mentioned in my previous posts are in /scratch.1 on tonic: /scratch/nleroy/workspace/trunk-classad/build-condor/src/classad_benchmarks
